info.name: Athena - v2 & v3
info.description:
# IBM Blockchain Platform
This collection contains all the apis for the IBM Blockchain Platform UI aka IBP console.

- IBP console APIs cover managing the IBP infrastructure and the UI server
- There are no Fabric APIs via IBP console APIs 
	- see [Fabric SDK documentation](https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/release-1.4/index.html) to use Fabric APIs
- All IBP console APIs that require a body require JSON
- Most IBP console APIs require authorization (see procedure below). APIs that don't are marked `public` in the name.

### v2.0.0

## Authorization for SaaS (IBP console session)
This auth allows an IBP console **Developer** to interact with IBP console APIs from the browser. This auth requires a session context which is typically provided by a browser. Though you can hi-jack a session created from your browser and run APIs from Postman.

1. To hi-jack your session, login to IBP console with your browser and open the browser's developer tools.
2. Find the `Storage` tab in the developer tools
3. Find the `Cookie` section
4. Find the IBP console cookie named `com.ibm.cloud.console.blockchain.optools`
5. Copy this session id value (it should resemble `s%3AqyG...`)
5. In the Postman request you want to use, create a header called `Cookie` and set the value `com.ibm.cloud.console.blockchain.optools=SESSION-ID-VALUE-HERE`
6. Good to go, fire the api. This session, and thus your auth will expire within 8 hours.

Note that none of this crap is needed to use the APIs from within Apollo. The browser will build this header by itself.

## Authorization for SaaS (IAM bearer)
This auth allows end users to interact with IBP console APIs from external scripts/applications.

To authorize your API calls you will need to provide an IAM **bearer token** (aka access token). The token can be sent in the http `Authorization` header with the following format:

`Authorization: Bearer xxxx.xxxx.xxxx`
***

This bearer/access token must be obtained out of band by the user. 

### Steps:

1. First create an IAM **API key**. You can create a key that has the same permissions as yourself here:
	- https://cloud.ibm.com/iam/apikeys
	- Click the "Create an IBM Cloud API key"
	- This key has the same permissions as **your** IBM ID identity

2. Next you need to exchange the api key for an IAM **token**. Copy/paste the api key into the curl command below and run it in a terminal/command prompt:
	- `curl -X POST https://iam.cloud.ibm.com/identity/token -H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded"  -H "Accept: application/json" -d "grant_type=urn%3Aibm%3Aparams%3Aoauth%3Agrant-type%3Aapikey&apikey=IAM-API-KEY-HERE"`
	- The response to this curl command is JSON and there is a field called `"access_token"`. This field contains your bearer token. Copy the value of this field (Note that copying the entire response will not work).
	- Use this value to create your `Authorization` header (format above)
	- If this token does not have 2 decimals (`.`) you have grabbed the wrong value.
	- An IAM bearer token is valid for 1 hour, thus you will need to repeat this in an hour

## Authorization for SaaS (IAM api key)
This auth allows end users to interact with IBP console APIs from external scripts/applications.

To authorize your API calls you will need to provide an IAM **api key**. The key can be sent in the http `Authorization` header with the following format:

`Authorization: ApiKey xxxx`
***

This api key must be obtained out of band by the user. 

### Steps:
1. Create an IAM **API key**. You can create a key that has the same permissions as yourself here:
	- https://cloud.ibm.com/iam/apikeys
	- Click the "Create an IBM Cloud API key"
	- Copy and use the api key value to create your `Authorization` header (format above)
	- This key has the same permissions as **your** IBM ID identity
	- An IAM api key is valid until it is deleted (does not expire)

## Authorization for Software (IBP console basic auth)
This auth allows end users to interact with IBP console APIs from external scripts/applications.

To authorize your API calls you will need to provide an IBP console **api key** && **api secret**. The value can be sent in the http `Authorization` header with the following format:

`Authorization: Basic GIBBERISH==`
***

Note - The string `GIBBERISH==` is an example, your value should be created by performing a base 64 string conversion on the `api_key` + `':'` + `api_secret`. (e.g. concate the `api_key`, a colon, and the `api_secret`. Then base 64 that string.)
***

This api key and secret must be obtained out of band by the user. 
Use your login username and password to generate an api key and api secret by following these steps:

### Steps:

1. Use the create-an-api-key API on IBP console. This API can be authorized with another api key or with your UI login credentials. Since you don't have an api key yet, use your login credentials. 
- The Postman example for this api can be found by clicking through the collection folders on the left: `Permissions -> API Keys -> Create api key - api key`.


- **Method**: POST
- **Route**: `/ak/api/v2/permissions/keys`
- **Auth**: (Http Header) `Authorization: Basic BoopBeep==`
	- The string `BoopBeep==` is an example, your value should be created by performing a base 64 string conversion on your `username` + `':'` + `password`. (e.g. concate the `username`, a colon, and the `password`. Then base 64 that string.)
- **Body**:
```js
{
    "roles": ["reader", "writer", "manager"],  // only these values are allowed, at least 1
    "description": "user defined string here"  //[optional]
}
```
- **Response**:
```js
{
    "api_key": "string",
    "api_secret": "string",   // [warning] the api_secret will be lost after this api
    "roles": ["<role>"],
    "message": "ok"
}
```
- The `api_secret` returned in the response **will not be recoverable ever again. Thus its important to record it externally.**

item.name: Bulk Delete by tag - aka delete raft cluster - session
Bulk Delete by tag - api key

request.description:
Delete many component in Kubernetes.
This api will delete the IBP console data of each component and the actual components in k8s.
**It finds and deletes all components with the matching tag.**
Tags are not case sensitive.
***
The `tags` field is an array of strings in all component docs.
Thus all components with a matching entry will get deleted.

While built for deleting "orderer-raft-clusters" by `cluster_id` this api will work on any component tag.

Expect a http status code of **207** when mixed results occur.

item.name: Update a peer - api key - v2

request.description:
Update/edit a component in kubernetes.
This api can change the cpu/memory settings, and Fabric version of the component.
This version will also update the IBP console data.

- **Auth**: `manager` role

item.name: Bulk update by tag  - api key

request.description:
Updates/edits many components in Kubernetes.
This api can change the cpu/memory settings, and Fabric version of the components.
This api will update the IBP console doc of each component and the actual components.
**It finds and updates all components with the matching tag.**
Tags are not case sensitive.

***

The `tags` field is an array of strings in all component docs.
Thus all components with a matching entry will get updated.

***

Expect a http status code of **207** when mixed results occur.

This api will append or remove admin certs to the components' file system.
Certificates will be parsed.
If invalid they will be skipped.
Duplicate certificates will also be skipped.
- **Auth**: `manager` role

Note this api does not destroy the component's deployment in Kubernetes if applicable.

Send the fields you want to edit in the body.
Omit fields you want left alone.

***
These fields are not editable: `'type', 'cluster_id', '_id', '_rev', 'id', 'timestamp'` (if included they are ignored).
**All other fields are editable**.
To get the list of current fields, fetch the component with the `Get a component` API.


The field `edited_timestamp` will be added or updated when the edit is made.

- **Auth**: `manager` or `writer` role

item.name: Bulk get component statuses - api key

request.description:
Get the status of multiple components at a time. aka batch status API.

- For a **CA** this api will call the component's `api_url` + `"/cainfo"` rest endpoint.
- For an **Orderer** this api will call the component's `operations_url` + `"/healthz"` rest endpoint.
- For an **Peer** this api will call the component's `operations_url` + `"/healthz"` rest endpoint.

A "good" status is if the url above responds with a 2xx or 3xx http status code.
Thus this is more of a "is this component reachable from athena" check, than a "is this component healthy" check.

Note that this code will **not** verify TLS certs on the component.
Thus self signed tls certs can be used by the components w/o issue.

Note that the http status code of this response will be `207` as long as IBP console does not encounter internal issues reading the database.
The client will not be able to tell if all of the statuses are good (or bad) from the response code of this request.
The client needs to inspect the object of component statuses in the response and look at each `status` field.
- **Auth**: `reader` role

This api can be used to returned the UI to a clean-ish state.

- **Auth**: `manager` role

- **Auth**: `reader` role

Create a user for the UI.
The API will register a users by a **username**.
The username is often an email address but it could be any unique string.
This API is intended for software only (saas must use IAM).

- Usernames are always brought to lowercase (will not error).
- All users to add should not already exist (will error and abort the api).
- Usernames cannot contain these characters: `<`, `>`, or `:` (will error and abort the api).
	- Usernames cannot contain the colon character because it would create impossible credentials for basic auth
- Username lengths must be >= the setting `min_username_len` and <= the setting `max_username_len` (will error and abort the api).
	- Check the [configuration readme](../env/README.md#Default-Settings-File) for default values.
- If 1 username encounter an errors, no usernames get created.
- The setting `default_user_password` will be the user's initial password. They will need to change their password on login.

For compatibility reasons with other auth schemes the user's `name` attribute (seen in some apis) gets derived from their `username`.
If `username` is an email then `name` is the first 20 chars before the `@` symbol.
Else `name` is the the first 20 chars.

- **Auth**: `manager` role

Create a user for the UI.
The API will register a users by a **username**.
The username is often an email address but it could be any unique string.
This API is intended for software only (saas must use IAM).

- Usernames are always brought to lowercase (will not error).
- All users to add should not already exist (will error and abort the api).
- Usernames cannot contain these characters: `<`, `>`, or `:` (will error and abort the api).
	- Usernames cannot contain the colon character because it would create impossible credentials for basic auth
- Username lengths must be >= the setting `min_username_len` and <= the setting `max_username_len` (will error and abort the api).
	- Check the [configuration readme](../env/README.md#Default-Settings-File) for default values.
- If 1 username encounter an errors, no usernames get created.
- The setting `default_user_password` will be the user's initial password. They will need to change their password on login.

For compatibility reasons with other auth schemes the user's `name` attribute (seen in some apis) gets derived from their `username`.
If `username` is an email then `name` is the first 20 chars before the `@` symbol.
Else `name` is the the first 20 chars.

- **Auth**: `manager` role

header.value: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/74.0.3729.169 Safari/537.36

request.description:
This is a workaround for an https IBP console server using an http **configtxlator**. 
Because the browsers won't allow mix-content aka http client reqs on a https domain.
Thus the browser can send its configtxlator request to this proxy route and the server will call the http configtxlator.
***
The target url (the one for configtxlator) is not sent in this API.
Rather, the server gets the url from the setting `CONFIGTXLATOR_URL_ORIGINAL`.
***
The body and headers in the initiating request are forwarded on to configtxlator.

- **Method**: Any (GET/POST/HEAD/DELETE/PUT/PATCH/OPTIONS)
- **Route**: `/configtxlator/?*`
- **Auth**: `reader` role
- **Body**: Plain text only
- **Response**: route dependent

request.description:
This is a TLS workaround for **peers** w/untrusted TLS certificates.
The browser can send a proxy http request to the server who will forward the call on to the grpc-web proxy.
The server will accept self signed certs.

- **Method**: Any (GET/POST/HEAD/DELETE/PUT/PATCH/OPTIONS)
- **Auth**: `reader` role
- **Example**: a `POST` request to `http://<athenas_url>/grpcwp/https://169.46.208.195:317266/peer.Endorser/ProcessProposal` will send a `POST` to `https://169.46.208.195:317266/peer.Endorser/ProcessProposal`. Body and headers are copied.

This is a CORS + self signed cert workaround for **CAs** (1.4.1 and lower CA's do not support CORS).
The browser can send a proxy request to IBP console who will call the CA.
This bypasses CORS and the server will accept the self signed cert if applicable.

- **Method**: Any (GET/POST/HEAD/DELETE/PUT/PATCH/OPTIONS)
- **Auth**: `reader` role
- **Example**: a `POST` request to `http://<athenas_url>/caproxy/https://169.46.208.195:317266/api/v2/identities` will send a `POST` to `https://169.46.208.195:317266/api/v2/identities`. Body and headers are copied.

Allows the browser to call things he may not be able to from the browser.

- **Method**: POST
- **Auth**: Must have action `blockchain.optools.view` in session

item.name: Init signature collection - channel (v1 hash) - signature

request.description:
Use this api to init a signature collection transaction.
It will also be used by IBP console to receive a signature collection tx from other OpToolians.
- **Method**: POST
- **Auth**: The header `Authorization` must be present and follow this format:
    - `Authorization: Signature <signature_b64>`
    - `Signature` - the word "Signature" followed by a single space, case sensitive
    - `<signature_b64>` - this is some identity's signature as base 64 over the body. **Use the stitch function [stitch.buildSigCollectionAuthHeader()](https://github.ibm.com/IBM-Blockchain/stitch/tree/master/docs#buildSigCollectionAuthHeader) to do all steps.** Creating it manually is a few steps:
        1. remove the `distribute` field
        1. sort the keys in the remaining body
        1. stringify the remaining body you are sending
        1. create a SHA 256 hash of the stringified body (hex string)
        1. sign this hash with a private key. (typically any identity's key will do, see next bullet)
        1. convert signature to base64. Use this value for `<signature_b64>`.
    - use the matching certificate to this private key in the body field: `authorize.certificate`. Note there are special rules on what certs will work, see comments near `authorize.certificate` field in body below.
    - 
```
	// the cert for the identity that created the "Authorization" header in this request.
	// note that this cert must be signed by a ca root cert (or intermediate) that has been imported OR
	// registered to the UI.
	// use api #8 in this file to "register" external MSPs or use the "import" MSP (api #1) in ./components.md.
	// the "import" MSP api is preferred.
	certificate: "<base 64 pem>",
```

item.name: Add sig to signature collection - channel (v1 hash) - signature

request.description:
Use this api to append a new signature, close a sig collection, or redistribute a sig collection.
It will also be used by IBP console to send/receive signatures from external IBP console.
***
Note APIs `/v1/` and `/v2/` take a similar body, but differ on how they authenticate the request.
V2's purpose is to edit OR redistribute the local signature tx doc w/o getting a new local signature.
It uses the permission based role's to authenticate.
While V1 requires the client to create a new `Authorization` header which includes a valid signature over the body.
***
The `/v1/` and `/v2/` apis can redistribute (meaning send the existing collection w/o changes) by having an empty `orgs2sign` and `orderers2sign` array in this body.
Also set `distribute` to `"all"`.
***
Its not possible for the `/v2/` api calls with populated `orgs2sign` or `orderers2sign` arrays to be authorized by external IBP console.
Since the permission based roles of one IBP console will not apply to another.
Thus the usage of `/v1/` is preferred when there are external IBP console that need to sign.
***
If using `/v2/` and the array `orgs2sign` or `orderers2sign` are populated you should set `distribute` to be `none`.
Since the redistribution call will be unable to authenticate due to the reasons above.
***
I know this is complicated, but just read the markdown docs carefully.

- **Route**:
	- v1 - `/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id` || `/ak/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id`
	- v2 - `/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id` || `/ak/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id`
- **Auth**:
	- v1 - The header `Authorization` must be present. See API #3 for full details.
	- v2 - Must have action `manager` role via basic auth

item.name: Add sig to signature collection - ccd (v2 hash)  - signature

request.description:
Use this api to append a new signature, close a sig collection, or redistribute a sig collection.
It will also be used by IBP console to send/receive signatures from external IBP console.
***
Note APIs `/v1/` and `/v2/` take a similar body, but differ on how they authenticate the request.
V2's purpose is to edit OR redistribute the local signature tx doc w/o getting a new local signature.
It uses the permission based role's to authenticate.
While V1 requires the client to create a new `Authorization` header which includes a valid signature over the body.
***
The `/v1/` and `/v2/` apis can redistribute (meaning send the existing collection w/o changes) by having an empty `orgs2sign` and `orderers2sign` array in this body.
Also set `distribute` to `"all"`.
***
Its not possible for the `/v2/` api calls with populated `orgs2sign` or `orderers2sign` arrays to be authorized by external IBP console.
Since the permission based roles of one IBP console will not apply to another.
Thus the usage of `/v1/` is preferred when there are external IBP console that need to sign.
***
If using `/v2/` and the array `orgs2sign` or `orderers2sign` are populated you should set `distribute` to be `none`.
Since the redistribution call will be unable to authenticate due to the reasons above.
***
I know this is complicated, but just read the markdown docs carefully.

- **Route**:
	- v1 - `/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id` || `/ak/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id`
	- v2 - `/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id` || `/ak/api/v2/signature_collections/:tx_id`
- **Auth**:
	- v1 - The header `Authorization` must be present. See API #3 for full details.
	- v2 - Must have action `manager` role via basic auth

This task can be accomplished with api "Init signature collection" with a modified body. 
Use the `/v2/` version with an empty `orgs2sign` array, `distribute` set to `"none"` and `status` set to either `"closed"` or `"open"`.
***

If you want the `closed` state to propagate to external IBP console, use the `/v1/` version of the api, build the auth header, and set `distribute` to `all`.

Archive a signature collection tx, aka dismiss a signature collection tx.
***
This will mark a sig collection txs as `"archive"` or `"inbox"`.
This api will NOT communicate to external IBP console.
Thus it is only for the local IBP console' management.
***
This does not close a tx (see api "Delete signature collection" for that).
It's a cosmetic attribute to filter/divide txs that the design team wanted.
- **Auth**: Must have action `blockchain.signaturecollection.manage`

Build a [Postman](https://www.getpostman.com) API Collection (response is JSON).

It can be imported to the Postman desktop application.
It will also be pre-populated with authorization credential material.

The authorization credentials must be provided to this API.
The query parameters `username` & `password` must be set with your IBP api key credentials.
